Posts.Content: My father has prostate cancer and he recently got a swelling in one leg. It came up quite quickly and has stayed. The Dr says that my fathers is due to the enlarged prostate pressing on the lymph system and stopping the drainage of the lymph fluid from one leg. I have tried to get my father to walk to see if that helps but he also gets very tired very quickly and the doctor told him that exercise will not help the swelling and to put his leg up to help ease the swelling. My experience with horses is that exercise does help get rid of swelling due to lymph fluid but my father will not even try to walk a bit due to his fatigue. Do not take what I am saying as being what is happening with your father but I just wanted to let you know of my similar observations with my father. My fathers prostate is advanced but has not metasised. Nick
Posts.Signature: Age 1/2 way to 120 plus 1. Symptom of blood in stools May 2011. Colonoscopy June 2011 confirmed rectal cancer. CT scan June 2011 showed no spread to other organs. Anterior resection July 2011 plus 50% bowel removed due to thickening observed during operation. Biopsy confirmed stage 2 in rectum only. Completed 8 cycles of precautionary capecitabine (4600mg Xeloda). Returned to horse riding 6 weeks post op, jumping 2weeks later and first competition 2 weeks after that. July 2012 - CT scan clear. June 2014 - CT scan clear. December 2014 - Colonoscopy clear. July 2017 - 6 year CT scan clear.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Completed today

Posts.Content: Hi, I am a visitor from over in the CRC forum. My 85 year old father has prostate cancer (Gleeson 4+4) and although the prostate is very significantly enlarged it is believed that the cancer is still confined within the prostate. The size of the prostate is such that it has moved on from just pressing on the urethra to where it is now affecting the flow in the ureters from the kidneys into the bladder. A stent was tried with some success for a while but the eventually the flow through that got impeded and the consultant decided that long term nephrostomies are the way forward. He has now had these fitted for 10 days and is at home. So far he seems very much better off. It is hoped that these will also help with his UTI problems which had started to be rather too regular. My father's request via me is whether there are any tips for dealing with the bags and pipes whilst in bed because he is finding them very restricting and is worried about trying to sleep any other way than on his back. In bed he leaves his leg bag on and then attaches that to a night bag on a stand on the floor beside the bed. (all x 2 of course). It's trivial stuff but it helps with the quality of life. Any thoughts? Many thanks, Nick

Posts.Title: Help with tips for coping with long term nephrostomy into both kidneys.

Posts.Content: Lancepeace Thanks for response. I think my father is a bit unusual in the way things are progressing. I have searched for nephrostomy on the forum and I must say it doesn't seem to crop up much. There may be more nephrostomy users with other things such as bladder c. Nick

Posts.Title: Help with tips for coping with long term nephrostomy into both kidneys.

Posts.Content: My father always had scans / X-rays to see whether there was any cancer in the bones that could be causing pain. Only that way could they be sure and then think about treatment. My father had radio therapy on his bone Mets and that was very effective for reducing pain. Nick

Posts.Title: Bone pain due to Prostate Cancer (M)

Posts.Content: Hi guys, My father passed away two years ago due to prostate cancer. His consultant advised me to get my PSA checked when all the dust had settled down. I was my fathers carer right up until the bitter end. Indeed he died in the room where I am typing this. It has taken two years for the dust to well and truly 'settle down' and for my life and brain to return to normal. I take my hat off to anyone who cares for another loved one. So I went to see the nice nurse today and gave the blood sample. Also handed over a urine sample that passed the dip test with no markers present. I go to see the doctor on Friday to get the results and to discuss anything that needs discussing. Hopefully it will be a passing acquaintance with this part of the forum but what will be will be. Nick

Posts.Title: Hi guys, hopefully just a temporary visit here to say hello.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Nick you simply won't know until you get to the landing side of the PSA fence! Good luck on Friday! ASAdvocate has provided solid suggestions. Specific to you, staying out of the saddle prior to a PSA test is also advisable. Glad you are vigilant. Remain so! MF I gave it just under 48 hrs of no riding. If a retest is on the cards I'll give it 72 hrs! Nick

Posts.Content: Hi, I went to the doctor to get the test results this morning. It's kind of a bad news / good news thing. Good news is the PSA was 1.0 which is OK for 63 years old. DRE was also normal. Bad news? I don't get to hang out with you guys. I guess I can put up with that. Take care and I my thoughts are with with you all. I will go back the CRC forum now. Nick
